elements.content: By introducing the flexible 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (btx) ligand into the molybdate system under the hydrothermal conditions, seven novel Keggin-based frameworks were obtained: [Ag(btx)]4[SiMo12O40]·2H2O (1), [Cu(btx)]4[SiMo12O40] (2), [Cu(btx)2]2[SiMo12O40] (3), [Zn(btx)2]2[SiMo12O40]·0.5H2O (4) and [M2(H2O)4(btx)3][SiMo12O40]·4H2O (M = Mn, Ni and Co) (5−7). Compound 1 contains 0D (zero dimensional) Keggin-based fragment, 1D polymer chain and 0D+1D poly-pseudo-rotaxane motif. Compound 2 exhibits interesting 1D+2D poly-pseudo-rotaxane architecture. Compound 3 has a 3D 4-connected diamond-related polymeric framework, which entraps the Keggin polyoxoanions into the stellate channels. Compound 4 contains isolated Keggin polyoxoanions and zipperlike polymer fragments, which are constructed from pairs of crumpled nets. Isostructural compounds 5−7 exhibit 2D→2D interpenetrated network structure featuring both polyrotaxane and polycatenane characters.

Isostructural compounds 5-7 exhibit 2D→2D interpenetrated network structure featuring both polyrotaxane and polycatenane characters.

elements.content: Seven new Keggin-based frameworks with flexible 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (btx) ligand were synthesized and their structures were determined. By virtue of the flexibility of the btx molecule, entangled structures of 0D+1D poly-pseudo-rotaxane (1), 1D+2D poly-pseudo-rotaxane (2) and 2D→2D interpenetration (5−7) were obtained, which are rare examples of predesigned polyoxoanions that are incorporated into the entangled coordination networks.
elements.clean_text: Seven new Keggin-based frameworks with flexible 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (btx) ligand were synthesized and their structures were determined. By virtue of the flexibility of the btx molecule, entangled structures of 0D+1D poly-pseudo-rotaxane (1), 1D+2D poly-pseudo-rotaxane (2) and 2D→2D interpenetration (5-7) were obtained, which are rare examples of predesigned polyoxoanions that are incorporated into the entangled coordination networks.

elements.content: The synthesis and characterization of coordination networks based on the idea of self-assembly of specifically designed building blocks has been an area of rapid growth in recent years. The motivation behind much of this activity has been provided by the prospect of generating a wide range of purpose-built materials with desired structures and useful properties such as electronic, magnetic, optical, and catalytic. Among the numerous metal-organic coordination polymers, crystal engineering based on transition metal ions and flexible N-donor bridging ligands has received a great deal of consideration because the flexible ligands have many degrees of flexibility and conformational freedom and hence greater structural diversity. In addition, the use of conformationally nonrigid ligands facilitates the formation of interesting motifs with peculiar features like entanglements, conformational polymorphism, supramolecular isomerism, and flexibility of the networks that can give different nanoporous behavior upon external stimuli, as defined by Carlucci and Ciani and co-workers. Entangled systems, including polyrotaxanes, polycatenations, interpenetration, molecular knots and so on, have captivated much attention of chemists because of their undisputed beauty and their potential applications. So far large quantities of coordination networks belonging to entangled systems have been reported in the literature. However, polyoxoanions acting as well-defined building units incorporated into the coordination networks featuring entangled character were seldom reported.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The synthesis and characterization of coordination networks based on the idea of self-assembly of specifically designed building blocks has been an area of rapid growth in recent years. The motivation behind much of this activity has been provided by the prospect of generating a wide range of purpose-built materials with desired structures and useful properties such as electronic, magnetic, optical, and catalytic. Among the numerous metal-organic coordination polymers, crystal engineering based on transition metal ions and flexible N-donor bridging ligands has received a great deal of consideration because the flexible ligands have many degrees of flexibility and conformational freedom and hence greater structural diversity. In addition, the use of conformationally nonrigid ligands facilitates the formation of interesting motifs with peculiar features like entanglements, conformational polymorphism, supramolecular isomerism, and flexibility of the networks that can give different nanoporous behavior upon external stimuli, as defined by Carlucci and Ciani and co-workers. Entangled systems, including polyrotaxanes, polycatenations, interpenetration, molecular knots and so on, have captivated much attention of chemists because of their undisputed beauty and their potential applications. So far large quantities of coordination networks belonging to entangled systems have been reported in the literature. However, polyoxoanions acting as well-defined building units incorporated into the coordination networks featuring entangled character were seldom reported.

elements.content: In previous studies it has been reported that the flexible bridging ligand 1,4-bix(imidazol-1-yl-methyl)benzene (bix) formed an infinite polyrotaxane network of [Ag2(bix)3(NO3)2] by reactions with silver nitrate and gave a 2D interpenetrated network of [Zn(bix)2(NO3)2·4.5H2O] by reactions with zinc nitrate which has both polyrotaxane and polycatenane characters. Considering that the 1,2,4-triazole rings in 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (btx) ligand provide more potential coordination sites than the imidazole rings in bix, and that the polyoxometalates which represent an outstanding class of structure-tunable building block exhibit unrivaled versatility and attractive guest absorption property, we introduce the btx ligand and transition metal ions into the Keggin POM system. Seven compounds, [Ag(C12H12N6)]4[SiMo12O40]·2H2O (1), [Cu(C12H12N6)]4[SiMo12O40] (2), [Cu(C12H12N6)2]2[SiMo12O40] (3), [Zn(C12H12N6)2]2[SiMo12O40]·0.5H2O (4) and [M2(H2O)4(C12H12N6)3][SiMo12O40]·4H2O (M = Mn, Ni and Co) (5−7), were isolated based on the above-mentioned considerations, in which compound 1 shows 0D+1D poly-pseudo-rotaxane architecture, compound 2 exhibits interesting 1D+2D poly-pseudo-rotaxane structure and compounds 5−7 exhibit the same 2D→2D interpenetrated network structure featuring both polyrotaxane and polycatenane characters.

Considering that the 1,2,4-triazole rings in 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (btx) ligand provide more potential coordination sites than the imidazole rings in bix, and that the polyoxometalates which represent an outstanding class of structure-tunable building block exhibit unrivaled versatility and attractive guest absorption property, we introduce the btx ligand and transition metal ions into the Keggin POM system. elements.content: All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and were used as received. The ligand btx was prepared according to the reported procedure. FTIR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded in range of 4000−400 cm−1 on a Bruker IFS 66v/S Fourier-transform infrared spectrometer. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out at a ramp rate of 5 °C min−1 in a helium atmosphere with a Shimadzu DTG-50 instrument. Powder XRD data were collected with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5406 Å) radiation on a Rigaku X-ray diffractometer. Emission spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer LS50B luminescence spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and were used as received. The ligand btx was prepared according to the reported procedure. FTIR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded in range of 4000-400 cm-1 on a Bruker IFS 66v/S Fourier-transform infrared spectrometer. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out at a ramp rate of 5 °C min-1 in a helium atmosphere with a Shimadzu DTG-50 instrument. Powder XRD data were collected with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5406 Å) radiation on a Rigaku X-ray diffractometer. Emission spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer LS50B luminescence spectrophotometer.

elements.content: The hydrothermal syntheses were carried out in poly(tetrafluoroethylene)-lined stainless steel containers under autogenous pressure. The reaction vessel was filled to approximately 60% of its volume capacity.
elements.clean_text:
Syntheses

The hydrothermal syntheses were carried out in poly(tetrafluoroethylene)-lined stainless steel containers under autogenous pressure. The reaction vessel was filled to approximately 60% of its volume capacity.

elements.content: Molybdic acid (0.12 g), silicic acid (0.02 g), AgNO3 (0.03 g), btx (0.04 g) and H2O (15 mL) were mixed and stirred at room temperature for 30 min. Those mixtures were adjusted with 4 M HCl to different pH values (pH 3.0−3.8) and then sealed in the Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 170 °C for 5 days. After slow cooling to room temperature, brown blocklike crystals 1 were obtained (yield: 60%). Anal. Calcd for C48H52N24Ag4SiMo12O42: C, 17.75; H, 1.61; N, 10.35. Found: C, 17.84; H, 1.82; N, 10.25. IR (solid KBr pellet, cm−1) of 1: 3497 (m), 3112 (w), 1621 (w), 1516 (s), 1437 (w), 1427 (w), 1385 (w), 1277 (s), 1209 (w), 1135 (s), 1023 (s), 984 (w), 951 (s), 904 (s), 788 (m), 671 (s), 638 (w), 536 (w), 507 (w).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data collections of complexes 1−7 were performed by using a R-AXIS RAPID II diffractometer at 293 K with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELXTL package. Generally, the hydrogen atoms of the ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. The hydrogen atoms attached to water in compounds 1 and 4−7 were not located but were included in the structure factor calculations. A summary of the crystallographic data and structural determination for them is provided in Table . Selected bond lengths and bond ranges of Si−O, Mo−O, M−N and M−O in compounds 1−7 are listed in Table S1 in the and Table , respectively. Crystallographic data for the structures reported in this paper have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center with CCDC numbers 703662−703668 for 1−7.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallographic Study

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data collections of complexes 1-7 were performed by using a R-AXIS RAPID II diffractometer at 293 K with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELXTL package. Generally, the hydrogen atoms of the ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. The hydrogen atoms attached to water in compounds 1 and 4-7 were not located but were included in the structure factor calculations. A summary of the crystallographic data and structural determination for them is provided in Table . Selected bond lengths and bond ranges of Si-O, Mo-O, M-N and M-O in compounds 1-7 are listed in Table S1 in the  and Table , respectively. Crystallographic data for the structures reported in this paper have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center with CCDC numbers 703662-703668 for 1-7.

As is well-known, saturated Keggin polyoxoanions, for tailor making new solid materials with multidimensional framework structures, are valuable building blocks, convenient and reliable. If they can be assembled into the predetermined structures, meanwhile maintaining their structural integrity throughout the reaction process, the possibility to control the framework of Keggin POM-based solid materials with highly specific and cooperative functions will be improved. However, several factors hinder their direct use as precursors such as starting materials, temperature, filling volume, stoichiometry, especially the reductibility of organic reductant species. In our case, compounds 1−7 were all synthesized by the hydrothermal reactions from molybdic acid, silicic acid, btx and their corresponding metal salt. We were also carried out the experiments from saturated H4SiMo12O40 original, corresponding metal salt and btx ligand in the same reaction conditions. However, only compounds 2 and 3 were obtained when using H4SiMo12O40, CuBr, btx and using H4SiMo12O40, Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O, btx, respectively. For the synthesis reactions of compounds 1 and 4−7, only mass precipitates were obtained.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

As is well-known, saturated Keggin polyoxoanions, for tailor making new solid materials with multidimensional framework structures, are valuable building blocks, convenient and reliable. If they can be assembled into the predetermined structures, meanwhile maintaining their structural integrity throughout the reaction process, the possibility to control the framework of Keggin POM-based solid materials with highly specific and cooperative functions will be improved. However, several factors hinder their direct use as precursors such as starting materials, temperature, filling volume, stoichiometry, especially the reductibility of organic reductant species. In our case, compounds 1-7 were all synthesized by the hydrothermal reactions from molybdic acid, silicic acid, btx and their corresponding metal salt. We were also carried out the experiments from saturated H4SiMo12O40 original, corresponding metal salt and btx ligand in the same reaction conditions. However, only compounds 2 and 3 were obtained when using H4SiMo12O40, CuBr, btx and using H4SiMo12O40, Cu(CH3COO)2⋅H2O, btx, respectively. For the synthesis reactions of compounds 1 and 4-7, only mass precipitates were obtained.

elements.content: The building block [SiMo12O40]4− (shortened as SiMo12) in compounds 1−7 exhibits the typical α-Keggin configuration which consists of one distorted [SiIVO4] tetrahedron surrounded by four [MoVI 3O13] sets. The [MoVI 3O13] sets are formed by three edge-sharing [MoO6] octahedra and are linked together through bridging oxygen atoms. The central atom Si is surrounded by a cube of eight oxygen atoms, with each oxygen site half-occupied. The bond valence sum calculations and the crystal color of each compound confirm that all the Mo centers are in +VI oxidation state. The Mo−O and Si−O lengths in these complexes are in the normal ranges (Table ).
elements.clean_text:
Description of the Crystal Structures

The building block [SiMo12O40]4- (shortened as SiMo12) in compounds 1-7 exhibits the typical α-Keggin configuration which consists of one distorted [SiIVO4] tetrahedron surrounded by four [MoVI 3O13] sets. The [MoVI 3O13] sets are formed by three edge-sharing [MoO6] octahedra and are linked together through bridging oxygen atoms. The central atom Si is surrounded by a cube of eight oxygen atoms, with each oxygen site half-occupied. The bond valence sum calculations and the crystal color of each compound confirm that all the Mo centers are in +VI oxidation state. The Mo-O and Si-O lengths in these complexes are in the normal ranges (Table ).

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) reveals that compound 1 contains 0D Keggin-based fragment and 1D polymer chain as well as 0D+1D poly-pseudo-rotaxane motif. As seen from Figure a, four basic fragments are included in compound 1, i.e. uncoordinated SiMo12 polyoxoanion, dinuclear molecular loop of [Ag(1)(btx)2]2+ and two kinds of cationic complexes of [Ag(2)(btx)]+ and [Ag(3)(btx)]+. All three unique Ag+ centers are coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from the triazole rings of two btx groups, which adopt the linear [AgN2] coordination geometry. The Ag−N distance is in the range of 2.043(18)−2.135(16) Å. Every two Ag(1) centers is connected through two V-shaped btx molecules to form a dinuclear molecular loop of [Ag(1)(btx)2]2+. Ag(2) and Ag(3) centers are bridged by the Z-shaped btx molecules to form two sorts of wavelike chains of [Ag(2)(btx)] n n+ and [Ag(3)(btx)] n n+, respectively. The adjacent Ag···Ag distances in the two chains are 13.000 Å and 14.084 Å, respectively. Uncoordinated SiMo12 polyoxoanions acting as the molds induce one kind of wavelike chain of [Ag(2)(btx)] n n+ to surround with them through short contact interactions (Ag(2)···O(12) = 3.107 Å and C(14)···O(12) = 2.999 Å), forming a polyoxoanion-templated layer structure (Figure b). Poly-pseudo-rotaxane structural character is observed between the binuclear molecular loop and wavelike chain [Ag(3)(btx)]+ in the manner shown in Figure c. In the lattice, the SiMo12-templated supramolecular layers and the 0D+1D poly-pseudo-rotaxane polymers are interlaced and interact together via short contact interactions (Ag(3)···O(19) = 2.941 Å and C(20)···O(9) = 3.207 Å) between polyoxoanions and [Ag(3)(btx)]+ chain (see Figure d).
elements.clean_text:
[Ag(btx)]4[SiMo12O40]⋅2H2O (1)

The single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) reveals that compound 1 contains 0D Keggin-based fragment and 1D polymer chain as well as 0D+1D poly-pseudo-rotaxane motif. As seen from Figure a, four basic fragments are included in compound 1, i.e. uncoordinated SiMo12 polyoxoanion, dinuclear molecular loop of [Ag(1)(btx)2]2+ and two kinds of cationic complexes of [Ag(2)(btx)]+ and [Ag(3)(btx)]+. All three unique Ag+ centers are coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from the triazole rings of two btx groups, which adopt the linear [AgN2] coordination geometry. The Ag-N distance is in the range of 2.043(18)-2.135(16) Å. Every two Ag(1) centers is connected through two V-shaped btx molecules to form a dinuclear molecular loop of [Ag(1)(btx)2]2+. Ag(2) and Ag(3) centers are bridged by the Z-shaped btx molecules to form two sorts of wavelike chains of [Ag(2)(btx)] n   n+ and [Ag(3)(btx)] n   n+, respectively. The adjacent Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distances in the two chains are 13.000 Å and 14.084 Å, respectively. Uncoordinated SiMo12 polyoxoanions acting as the molds induce one kind of wavelike chain of [Ag(2)(btx)] n   n+ to surround with them through short contact interactions (Ag(2)⋅⋅⋅O(12) = 3.107 Å and C(14)⋅⋅⋅O(12) = 2.999 Å), forming a polyoxoanion-templated layer structure (Figure b). Poly-pseudo-rotaxane structural character is observed between the binuclear molecular loop and wavelike chain [Ag(3)(btx)]+ in the manner shown in Figure c. In the lattice, the SiMo12-templated supramolecular layers and the 0D+1D poly-pseudo-rotaxane polymers are interlaced and interact together via short contact interactions (Ag(3)⋅⋅⋅O(19) = 2.941 Å and C(20)⋅⋅⋅O(9) = 3.207 Å) between polyoxoanions and [Ag(3)(btx)]+ chain (see Figure d).

elements.content: In order to evaluate the influence of charge of the metal cations on the structure of the complexes, reactions of btx and polyoxometalate with metal salts of CuBr and Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O were performed respectively, and complexes 2 and 3 were obtained successfully. Single-crystal XRD analysis shows that complex 2 crystallizes in the triclinic system with the P1̅ space group. As shown in Figure a, there are three crystallographically independent CuI centers, in which Cu(1) and Cu(2) are half-occupied. The Cu(1) and Cu(2) centers are both coordinated in a linear geometry of [CuN2] by two nitrogen atoms from two btx ligands. The bond lengths are in the normal range (see Table S1 in the ). The Cu(3) center is four-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two btx ligands and two oxygen atoms from two SiMo12 polyoxoanions in a “seesaw style”. The bond distances and angles around Cu(3) are 1.860(18) and 1.867(17) Å (Cu−N), 2.772(3) and 2.634(4) Å (Cu−O), 178.13(3)° (N−Cu−N), and 87.76(4)−92.61(3)° (N−Cu−O), comparable to those of other similar four-coordinated copper(I) complexes. Each SiMo12 cluster acts as a tetradentate ligand which is covalently bonding to four [Cu(3)(btx)]+ complexes via its four terminal oxygen atoms (O(15), O(15)*, O(17) and O(17)*), resulting in a layer structure with square meshes that contains Keggin-based fragments grafted by double bitrack [Cu(3)(btx)] n n+ chains, as shown in Figure b. The [Cu(1)(btx)] n n+ polymeric chains surround and interact with the SiMo12 clusters in the layer via short contacts (C(1)···O(8) = 3.097 Å, C(3)···O(16) = 3.172 Å and C(4)···O(16) = 3.187 Å).

All the btx molecules in the [Cu(btx)] n n+ chains exhibit the Z-shaped conformation.

elements.content: It is interesting that when the Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O was introduced in the reaction of btx with polyoxometalate, complex 3 with total different structure was obtained. XRD reveals that 3 crystallizes in a monoclinic system, space group P21/n. The structure of 3 consists of two Cu2+ ions, four btx ligands, and one SiMo12 polyoxoanion. Each Cu2+ ion is surrounded by four equatorial nitrogen atoms (N(1), N(4), N(7) and N(12)) from four btx molecules and two oxygen atoms (O(9) and O(13)) from two SiMo12 clusters in a regular octahedral geometry (Figure a). If only the CuII centers and btx ligands are taken into account, we get a 3D polymeric framework with stellate channel dimensions of ca. 19.1 × 9.9 Å viewing along the [100] direction (Figure b). A better insight into the nature of such 3D framework can be achieved by reducing the multidimensional structure to simple node-and-linker net. According to the simplification principle, the CuII center is defined as a 4-connected node and the btx ligating with two CuII centers serves as a linker. Therefore, the resulting 3D polymer is a uninodal 4-connected diamond-related net with Schläfli symbol of 66, as shown in Figure c. Furthermore, each SiMo12 cluster connects with four adjacent clusters through four covalent (O(13)−Cu-O(9)) linkages and inserts regularly in the stellate channel by coordinating with four apical CuII centers in it (Figure d). All the btx molecules in this compound exhibit the Z-shaped conformation. By comparing compound 2 with 3, we can conclude that the valence of Cu is the key factor causing the topological difference between them.

elements.content: XRD reveals that compound 4 is composed of two kinds of subunits, i.e. isolated SiMo12 polyoxoanion and [Zn(btx)2]2+ cationic building block (Figure a). In the cationic subunit, the ZnII center is in tetrahedral coordination environment, coordinated by four nitrogen atoms from two sorts of btx ligands in Z-shaped and L-shaped conformation. The cationic subunit further expands to form a 2D crumpled net with quadrate channel dimensions of ca. 13.4 × 12.4 Å (Figure b). The Z-shaped btx ligands become pendants of the 2D net, projecting toward the same side of the net. Pairs of such nets pack along the c axis of the crystal with the pendants protruding into the voids of the adjacent net. In this way, an interesting zipper-like structure is established. Furthermore, the SiMo12 polyoxoanions insert in the adjacent “zippers” via short contact interactions (C(1)···O(1) = 3.145 Å, C(23)···O(1) = 3.030 Å and N(10)···O(1) = 3.066 Å), as shown in Figure c.

elements.content: XRD studies performed on compounds 5−7 indicate that they exhibit the same 2D→2D interpenetrated network structure which has both polyrotaxane and polycatenane characters; thus, only the structure of 5 is described here in detail. Compound 5 is constructed from one SiMo12 polyoxoanion, two Mn2+ ions, three btx molecules, four coordinated water and four lattice water molecules (Figure a). Each MnII center is surrounded by three nitrogen atoms from three btx molecules, one terminal oxygen atom from one SiMo12 cluster and two water molecules. For the three btx molecules, two of them exhibit V-shaped conformation and another one exhibits Z-shaped conformation. The two V-shaped btx molecules together with two Mn2+ ions constitute one type of [Mn2(btx)2]4+ dinuclear molecular loop. Each SiMo12 cluster is bridged by two [Mn2(btx)2]4+ loops to form an 1D extension. The Z-shaped btx molecules arrange perpendicularly to the direction of the chain propagation and therefore extend the chains into a 2D net with quadrate channel dimensions of ca. 14.3 × 22.2 Å (Figure b). Two such nets penetrate each other with each loop in one layer threaded by rods of the other layer so as to form a 2-fold parallelly interpenetrated network featuring the polyrotaxane nature, as shown in the Figure c. Furthermore, the 2-fold nets also exhibit the polycatenane character as the smallest rings (dinuclear molecular loop) of one net are involved in catenane associations with the second-smallest rings (six-nuclear molecular loop through two SiMo12 clusters) of the other net. The topology of this case is unusual and it is amazing that the manner of interpenetrating in this compound is much similar to that in compound [Zn(bix)2](NO3)2·4.5H2O if the SiMo12 polyoxoanion is considered as a linker. The 2-fold nets pack along the b axis of the crystal via extensive O−H···O hydrogen bond interactions.

elements.content: To investigate their thermal stabilities, thermal gravimetric analyses were performed for compounds 1−7 (as shown in Figure S1 in the ). The TGA curve shows that compound 1 loses 2 lattice water molecules from 70 to 180 °C with the observed mass loss of 1.06%, which is consistent with the theoretical value of 1.10%. The remaining structure starts to collapse above 270 °C with the loss of 4 btx ligands per formula unit and decomposition does not end until heating to 600 °C. Compounds 2 and 3 remain intact until they are heated to 314 and 270 °C, respectively, and then mass losses occur which are attributed to the release of 4 btx ligands per formula unit for each other. For compound 4, the first weight loss from room temperature to 100 °C corresponds to the loss of 0.5 crystalline water molecule which is followed by a steady plateau up to 338 °C. Then, the framework starts to collapse with the loss of 4 btx molecules per formula unit. Compounds 5−7 have similar thermal stability and are stable up to 310 °C. The first weight loss from room temperature to 310 °C corresponds to the loss of 4 lattice water molecules and 4 coordinated water molecules with the observed value of 4.56% for 5, 4.74% for 6 and 4.78% for 7. The remaining structure was broke down above 310 °C with the release of 3 btx molecules and decomposition does not end until heating to 600 °C.

Thermal Stability Analysis

To investigate their thermal stabilities, thermal gravimetric analyses were performed for compounds 1-7 (as shown in Figure S1 in the ). The TGA curve shows that compound 1 loses 2 lattice water molecules from 70 to 180 °C with the observed mass loss of 1.06%, which is consistent with the theoretical value of 1.10%. The remaining structure starts to collapse above 270 °C with the loss of 4 btx ligands per formula unit and decomposition does not end until heating to 600 °C. Compounds 2 and 3 remain intact until they are heated to 314 and 270 °C, respectively, and then mass losses occur which are attributed to the release of 4 btx ligands per formula unit for each other. For compound 4, the first weight loss from room temperature to 100 °C corresponds to the loss of 0.5 crystalline water molecule which is followed by a steady plateau up to 338 °C. Then, the framework starts to collapse with the loss of 4 btx molecules per formula unit. Compounds 5-7 have similar thermal stability and are stable up to 310 °C. The first weight loss from room temperature to 310 °C corresponds to the loss of 4 lattice water molecules and 4 coordinated water molecules with the observed value of 4.56% for 5, 4.74% for 6 and 4.78% for 7. The remaining structure was broke down above 310 °C with the release of 3 btx molecules and decomposition does not end until heating to 600 °C.

elements.content: The luminescent properties of free ligand btx and the polymeric compounds of 1, 2 and 4 were investigated in the solid state, as depicted in Figure S2 in the . Upon excitation at 262 nm, free btx exhibits strong emission at 289 nm and weak emissions at ca. 365 and 421 nm. For the polymeric compounds, emission bands at ca. 379, 420, and 457 nm for 1, 380, 418, and 457 nm for 2, 378, 417, and 458 nm for 4 were observed under the same conditions. In comparison with the free ligand btx, the emission bands are bathochromic and have changed largely. The fluorescent emissions can be tentatively assigned to the metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) or ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT).
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

The luminescent properties of free ligand btx and the polymeric compounds of 1, 2 and 4 were investigated in the solid state, as depicted in Figure S2 in the . Upon excitation at 262 nm, free btx exhibits strong emission at 289 nm and weak emissions at ca. 365 and 421 nm. For the polymeric compounds, emission bands at ca. 379, 420, and 457 nm for 1, 380, 418, and 457 nm for 2, 378, 417, and 458 nm for 4 were observed under the same conditions. In comparison with the free ligand btx, the emission bands are bathochromic and have changed largely. The fluorescent emissions can be tentatively assigned to the metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) or ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT).

elements.content: In summary, seven new Keggin-based frameworks have been successfully prepared and structurally characterized which include various structural motifs with different dimensionality and topology: 0D, 0D+1D poly-pseudo-rotaxane, 1D+2D poly-pseudo-rotaxane and 2D→2D interpenetrated frameworks. The structural variety of these species is related to the flexibility of the btx ligand which has two types of conformation of V-shaped and Z-shaped. This work represents one of the rare reports on that the predesigned polyoxoanion is incorporated into the coordination network which exhibits entangled character. Furthermore, this work will undoubtedly deepen our systematic understanding of the structural functionality and the conformation flexibility of the btx molecule. Further work is in progress to prepare novel topologically structural complexes based on btx and a lengthened molecule of 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, seven new Keggin-based frameworks have been successfully prepared and structurally characterized which include various structural motifs with different dimensionality and topology: 0D, 0D+1D poly-pseudo-rotaxane, 1D+2D poly-pseudo-rotaxane and 2D→2D interpenetrated frameworks. The structural variety of these species is related to the flexibility of the btx ligand which has two types of conformation of V-shaped and Z-shaped. This work represents one of the rare reports on that the predesigned polyoxoanion is incorporated into the coordination network which exhibits entangled character. Furthermore, this work will undoubtedly deepen our systematic understanding of the structural functionality and the conformation flexibility of the btx molecule. Further work is in progress to prepare novel topologically structural complexes based on btx and a lengthened molecule of 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl.

Those mixtures were adjusted with 4 M HCl to different pH values (pH 3.0−3.8) and then sealed in the Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 170 °C for 5 days. After slow cooling to room temperature, brown blocklike crystals 1 were obtained (yield: 60%). Anal. Calcd for C48H52N24Ag4SiMo12O42: C, 17.75; H, 1.61; N, 10.35. Found: C, 17.84; H, 1.82; N, 10.25. Molybdic acid (0.12 g), silicic acid (0.02 g), AgNO3 (0.03 g), btx (0.04 g) and H2O (15 mL) were mixed and stirred at room temperature for 30 min. cln_elements.content:
To investigate their thermal stabilities, thermal gravimetric analyses were performed for compounds 1−7 (as shown in Figure S1 in the ). The TGA curve shows that compound 1 loses 2 lattice water molecules from 70 to 180 °C with the observed mass loss of 1.06%, which is consistent with the theoretical value of 1.10%. The remaining structure starts to collapse above 270 °C with the loss of 4 btx ligands per formula unit and decomposition does not end until heating to 600 °C. Compounds 2 and 3 remain intact until they are heated to 314 and 270 °C, respectively, and then mass losses occur which are attributed to the release of 4 btx ligands per formula unit for each other. For compound 4, the first weight loss from room temperature to 100 °C corresponds to the loss of 0.5 crystalline water molecule which is followed by a steady plateau up to 338 °C. Then, the framework starts to collapse with the loss of 4 btx molecules per formula unit. Compounds 5−7 have similar thermal stability and are stable up to 310 °C. The first weight loss from room temperature to 310 °C corresponds to the loss of 4 lattice water molecules and 4 coordinated water molecules with the observed value of 4.56% for 5, 4.74% for 6 and 4.78% for 7. The remaining structure was broke down above 310 °C with the release of 3 btx molecules and decomposition does not end until heating to 600 °C.

Luminescent Properties

The luminescent properties of free ligand btx and the polymeric compounds of 1, 2 and 4 were investigated in the solid state, as depicted in Figure S2 in the . Upon excitation at 262 nm, free btx exhibits strong emission at 289 nm and weak emissions at ca. 365 and 421 nm. For the polymeric compounds, emission bands at ca. 379, 420, and 457 nm for 1, 380, 418, and 457 nm for 2, 378, 417, and 458 nm for 4 were observed under the same conditions. In comparison with the free ligand btx, the emission bands are bathochromic and have changed largely. The fluorescent emissions can be tentatively assigned to the metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) or ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT).

Thermal Stability Analysis

To investigate their thermal stabilities, thermal gravimetric analyses were performed for compounds 1-7 (as shown in Figure S1 in the ). The TGA curve shows that compound 1 loses 2 lattice water molecules from 70 to 180 °C with the observed mass loss of 1.06%, which is consistent with the theoretical value of 1.10%. The remaining structure starts to collapse above 270 °C with the loss of 4 btx ligands per formula unit and decomposition does not end until heating to 600 °C. Compounds 2 and 3 remain intact until they are heated to 314 and 270 °C, respectively, and then mass losses occur which are attributed to the release of 4 btx ligands per formula unit for each other. For compound 4, the first weight loss from room temperature to 100 °C corresponds to the loss of 0.5 crystalline water molecule which is followed by a steady plateau up to 338 °C. Then, the framework starts to collapse with the loss of 4 btx molecules per formula unit. Compounds 5-7 have similar thermal stability and are stable up to 310 °C. The first weight loss from room temperature to 310 °C corresponds to the loss of 4 lattice water molecules and 4 coordinated water molecules with the observed value of 4.56% for 5, 4.74% for 6 and 4.78% for 7. The remaining structure was broke down above 310 °C with the release of 3 btx molecules and decomposition does not end until heating to 600 °C.

Luminescent Properties

The luminescent properties of free ligand btx and the polymeric compounds of 1, 2 and 4 were investigated in the solid state, as depicted in Figure S2 in the . Upon excitation at 262 nm, free btx exhibits strong emission at 289 nm and weak emissions at ca. 365 and 421 nm. For the polymeric compounds, emission bands at ca. 379, 420, and 457 nm for 1, 380, 418, and 457 nm for 2, 378, 417, and 458 nm for 4 were observed under the same conditions. In comparison with the free ligand btx, the emission bands are bathochromic and have changed largely. The fluorescent emissions can be tentatively assigned to the metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) or ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT).
